head.title: Homo Sapiens, Uneasy in the Pristine Sea

hedline.hl1: Homo Sapiens, Uneasy in the Pristine Sea

abstract.p: Dan Brumbaugh letter comments on July 27 editorial on shark attack against 8-year-old Jesse Arbogast off Pensacola, Fla

block.p: Although the oceans remain mysterious (editorial, July 27), they are no longer wildernesses. Overfishing, habitat destruction, pollution of freshwater runoff and apparent global climate change have indeed contributed to their degradation.

Only minuscule fractions of our coastlines are protected. When California, for example, inventoried its array of ''marine-protected areas,'' it found that only 0.2 percent qualified as wildernesses where various harmful activities were prohibited and all species were protected.

Although the oceans remain mysterious (editorial, July 27), they are no longer wildernesses. Overfishing, habitat destruction, pollution of freshwater runoff and apparent global climate change have indeed contributed to their degradation.

Only minuscule fractions of our coastlines are protected. When California, for example, inventoried its array of ''marine-protected areas,'' it found that only 0.2 percent qualified as wildernesses where various harmful activities were prohibited and all species were protected.

The recent decisions to designate large new marine reserve areas in the northwest Hawaiian Islands and the Florida Keys are important milestones, but we have a long way to go before we can be assured that the remaining seas will survive to inspire and support our descendants.
The writer is marine program manager at the American Museum of Natural History's Center for Biodiversity and Conservation.
